newsitem.title: UK: MOTOR RACING-BARRICHELLO SIGNS THREE-YEAR DEAL WITH STEWART. [corrected 20:43 gmt]
newsitem.headline: MOTOR RACING-BARRICHELLO SIGNS THREE-YEAR DEAL WITH STEWART. [corrected 20:43 gmt]

text.p: The Stewart Grand Prix team said on Tuesday they had signed Brazilian Rubens Barrichello to a three-year contract but added they did not expect him to bring them overnight success.
The 24-year-old Brazilian will team up with Denmark's Jan Magnussen at the Scottish Ford-powered team after four years with Jordan.
"We are delighted to have Rubens with us from the start," said team head and former world champion Jackie Stewart.
"We said from the outset that we want a driver with Formula One experience alongside a young, up-and-coming talent.
"Rubens brings the experience to complement the raw talent of Jan, but he is still young himself and can continue to develop as he helps us to build the team.

"We invested six million pounds sterling ($9.60 million) this year in technology alone," Stewart said, adding that total investment would be between 20 million and 25 million pounds ($32 to $40 million). (Corrects dollar conversion)
"Our car will be the first ever in Formula One to be produced exclusively by computer design."
Stewart said the team's first car would be ready by mid-December and tested early next year but conceded Grand Prix success could be a long time coming.
"We can't expect to be successful too soon. I am a Scottish man. I am conservative. We want to be competitive in a five-year period," he said.
Barrichello added: "The kind of opportunity I have been presented with by Stewart-Ford doesn't come along every day, the chance to build a new Formula One team from the ground up."
Earlier this month, Magnussen, 23, agreed to a four-year contract with the team who will make their debut in the 1997 season opener in Australia next March.
Barrichello's replacement at Jordan has yet to be announced.
In Portugal, German Heinz-Harald Frentzen, who takes over from world champion Damon Hill at Williams next season, had his first test drive for his new team.
The 29-year-old, who is still contracted to Swiss team Sauber, completed 54 laps at Portugal's Estoril circuit.
"The important task today was to try different seat positions and a two-pedal set-up which I am not used to," he said.
"I have very good impressions of the car and the team but I do not wish to give too many details away because I am still officially working with Sauber."
